definitions.sensetop: ring somebody/something upring somebody/somethingring (up)ring for something
definitions.labels: (British English)North American English, British EnglishBritish EnglishNorth American EnglishNorth American EnglishBritish EnglishBritish EnglishNorth American EnglishBritish English

examples.text: I'll ring you up later.
He rang up the police station.
When is the best time to ring New York?
I'll ring you later.
Concerned residents can write or ring my office.
David rang up while you were out.
He said he was ringing from London.
I'm ringing about your advertisement in the paper.
She rang to say she'd be late.
Could you ring for a cab?
We rang for an ambulance and he was taken to hospital.

definitions.definition: to make a sound because somebody is trying to phone you

examples.text: Will you answer the telephone if it rings?
The phone rang and rang *(= rang for a long time)* until eventually someone answered.
I'm just waiting for the phone to ring.

definitions.definition: if you ring a bell or if a bell rings, it produces a sound

examples.text: Someone was ringing the doorbell.
The church bells rang.
The doorbell rang loudly.
Just ring for the nurse *(= attract the nurse's attention by ringing a bell)* if you need her.
She climbed out of bed and rang for her maid.

definitions.definition: to be full of a sound; to fill a place with sound

examples.text: The house rang with children's laughter.
Applause rang through the hall.

definitions.definition: to be full of a particular quality

examples.text: His words rang with pride.

definitions.definition: to be uncomfortable and be unable to hear clearly, usually because you have heard a loud noise, etc.

examples.text: The music was so loud it made my ears ring.

definitions.definition: if you say that alarm bells are ringing, you mean that people are starting to feel worried and to suspect that something is wrong

examples.text: The government’s proposal has set alarm bells ringing for people on low incomes.

definitions.definition: to sound familiar to you, as though you have heard it before

examples.text: His name rings a bell but I can't think where we met.

definitions.definition: to make changes to something in order to have greater variety

examples.text: Ring the changes with a new colour.

definitions.definition: to make you feel that you can still hear something

examples.text: His warning was still ringing in my ears.

definitions.definition: to ring many times, with one phone call after another

examples.text: The phone has been ringing off the hook with offers of help.

definitions.definition: to give the impression of being sincere/true or not sincere/true

examples.text: It may seem a strange story but it rings true to me.
His expressions of support rang rather hollow.
His promise rang hollow.

wordOrigin: Old English hringan, of Germanic origin, perhaps imitative.
